Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Hot Extrusion of High-Strength Aluminum Alloys with Rotary Porthole Dies

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Due to their outstanding strength-to-weight ratios, high-strength aluminum alloys are widely used in the automotive, defense, and aerospace industries, as well as in construction and anywhere weight savings are desired. Among the different manufacturing methods used on these materials, hot extrusion is the most efficient production process to produce parts with a constant cross-section. However, even at very high temperature, some attractive aluminum alloys have very low extrudability, limiting their wider application. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is intended to solve this problem by exploring the feasibility of a new hot extrusion process with a rotary porthole die. If successful, the research will be expanded to investigate performance of a wider range of alloys, which ultimately will increase production rate of high-strength aluminum. The fundamental scientific and technological advances made will also be applicable to other difficult-to-extrude alloys. Because superior aluminum alloys could then be used across many industries, greater weight savings than is currently possible would become routine. In addition, because extrusion is a near net-shape process, finishing operations would be reduced and the cost of these aerospace alloys could decrease.

This project will deliver a new extrusion method and scientific findings for improving the extrusion of aluminum alloys, and create a model for extruding other difficult-to-extrude alloys, via metal flow control. Since the full-scale exploration of the envisioned rotary porthole die concept is associated with high risk and cost, in this EAGER project the concept a rotary porthole die will be demonstrated through a set of stationary twist-grove dies. In previous work, in-process material microstructural changes have been observed in conventional porthole dies. This finding suggests that a rotary porthole die might allow the control of the material flow to impart microstructural changes, resulting in production improvements. This research will involve the production of a testbed for with a twist-groove porthole die to demonstrate the process. At the same time, modeling will be performed to investigate metal flow in rotating porthole dies. The understanding of the metal flow path and its effects on microstructure, as a function of process variables such as temperature and deformation, will enable the control of the mechanical properties of the extruded products and increase the process efficiency. The goal is to provide a proof-of-concept of this new manufacturing process, which then provides a path for widespread use of difficult-to-form lightweight alloys.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal offers an innovative solution for high-strength aluminum alloy extrusion acceleration using a new concept of in-process microstructure modification induced by severe plastic deformation. This technique can be potentially utilized to advance the processes which face the challenges of forming alloys with high-strength and poor formability. This proposal intends to understand mechanism and phenomena taking place in a die in order to control microstructure of material i.e. grain refinement. The obtained knowledges are a database to develop a rotary porthole die for high-strength aluminum alloy extrusion. The rotary porthole die show in Figure 1. The findings will contribute toward answers to questions:

(1) How to maximize the extrusion speed of high-strength AA7075 and other difficult-to-extrude materials without tearing and deterioration of their high-strength properties.

Among aluminum alloys, AA7075 is the lowest extrusion speed due to tearing easy occurring on surface of profiles. In process of hot extrusion conditions, at high temperature conditions affect the extrusion speed becoming slow to avoid tearing. The extrusion speed is accelerated by a new process with a rotary porthole die in order to control microstructure change in a die during hot extrusion. The concept is to induce severe deformation into materials leading to grain refinement to improve material formability. It is similar to ultrafine grain structures improve material formability of hard materials. This mechanism can be used for a knowledge base to develop a rotary porthole die.

(2) How to carry out and what are the mechanisms of in-process microstructure modification by severe plastic deformation during extrusion.

Microstructure is improved by severe deformation leading to grain refinement in a die during hot extrusion of high strength alloys. To understand the mechanism and phenomena taking place in a die, the twist-groove porthole die was fabricated and used for experiment. The grooves were made to have a helical on surface inside a porthole portion from entrance to exit of the porthole portion. Twist-groove porthole design show in Figure 2 1) The twist-groove porthole die show in Figure 3. As obtained simulation results show in Figure 4 1). It shows that deformation in term of strain rate taking place in a die. Strain rate is increased with increase twist angle. Moreover, for experiment results, AA7075 microstructure of residual materials by using twist-groove porthole die. It can be seen a small grain size as shown in Figure 5 1). There are clearly seen that the grain refinement is induced by severe deformation taking pace in a die. It confirms that the mechanisms emerge of in-process microstructure modification by severe plastic deformation during extrusion. Base on this mechanisms, the rotary porthole die will be fabricated in order to control microstructure i.e. grain refinement to accelerate extrusion speed of high strength alloys.

(3) How does the metal flow path and temperature affect the microstructure and mechanical properties of the extruded parts. The in-process microstructure modification technique will also add additional merit to overall process simplification by removing the post-process heat treatment requirement.

In hot extrusion process, metal flow through a porthole portion, chamber and die orifice to obtain a desired shape of profiles. During hot extrusion, metal flow through a die, shear deformation, strain, and strain rate are also occurred. In this proposal, metal flow path is controlled by twist-groove in a porthole portion. Material is flowing while shear deformation take place, consequently grain refinement induced. Flow stress of high strength alloys e.g. AA7075 is high. It can be reduced by increase temperature conditions to improve formability of materials. Generally, high strength alloys have been widely produced at high temperature condition. Because of temperature affects the formability of material by decreasing flow stress of materials leading to soft strength. Therefore, materials is easy formed and easy flow through a die in hot extrusion. However, tearing and deterioration easy occur on products. Moreover, temperature is increased by friction at the contact interface of materials and tools. It affects the recrystallization becoming large grain size of extruded parts.

References

S. Ngernbamrung, Y. Suzuki, N. Takatsuji, K. Dohda, Investigation of surface cracking of hot extruded AA7075 billet, Prociadia Manufacturing, Vol. 15 (2018) 217-224.
